docs.snippet: Lucine Amara and the Metropolitan opera have settled their differences -Miss Amara's complaint was that the management had discriminated against her on the ground of age - and the soprano returned to the Met stage on Thursday night, after an absen...
docs.lead_paragraph: Lucine Amara and the Metropolitan opera have settled their differences -Miss Amara's complaint was that the management had discriminated against her on the ground of age - and the soprano returned to the Met stage on Thursday night, after an absence of four years, as Amelia in ''Un Ballo in Maschera.'' This performance also marked the 30th anniversary of her debut season.

docs.snippet: In an era when operatic settings more often than not tend toward the forbiddingly abstract and chillingly spare, Beni Montresor's sensual uses of fabrics, forms, color and light proclaim him to be one of the few genuine romantics in the field of o...
docs.lead_paragraph: In an era when operatic settings more often than not tend toward the forbiddingly abstract and chillingly spare, Beni Montresor's sensual uses of fabrics, forms, color and light proclaim him to be one of the few genuine romantics in the field of operatic stage design. Many New Yorkers are familiar with his lush productions of ''La Gioconda,'' ''Esclarmonde'' and ''The Last Savage'' at the Metropolitan Opera, and the City Opera's repertory contains three notable Montresor conceptions, ''The Magic Flute,'' ''Turandot'' and ''The Daughter of the Regiment.'' This year marks the 20th anniversary of Mr. Montresor's first operatic undertaking, Samuel Barber's ''Vanessa'' at the Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds, and to celebrate the occasion, a retrospective of his designs is on view at the Lincoln Center Library for the Performing Arts, where it may be seen every day except Wednesdays and Sundays until April 11 (Monday and Thursday, 10 A.M. to 7:45 P.M.; Tuesday, to 5:45, and Friday and Saturday, noon to 5:45). On display are the costumes, stage models and set designs of nearly 30 operas produced over the last two decades in Paris, San Francisco, Venice, Munich, London, Houston and Toulouse, France, as well as in New York.

headline.main: 20 YEARS OF STAGE DESIGN BY MONTRESSOR ON DISPLAY

docs.snippet: IMPRESSIONIST, modern and post World War II art goes on the block at three of New York's top art-auction houses in the next two weeks, although the sales mostly offer works of moderate and lower prices.  The first sale is next Wednesday at 2 P.M. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: IMPRESSIONIST, modern and post World War II art goes on the block at three of New York's top art-auction houses in the next two weeks, although the sales mostly offer works of moderate and lower prices. The first sale is next Wednesday at 2 P.M. at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, where the top lot is a small Renoir painting depicting a young girl, an oil that was once owned by Paulette Goddard, the actress. It is estimated to sell for as much as $100,000. Other notable offerings are Marie Laurencin's ''Woman With Cats,'' a 1920 oil on canvas (up to $70,000); Fernand Leger's ''Man and Melon, No. 2,'' a 1938 oil on canvas (up to $75,000), and Chaim Soutine's ''The Little Girl at the Gate,'' an oil on canvas laid down on board, from about 1939, which was exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art's 1950-51 Soutine retrospective (up to $55,000). Next Thursday at 2 P.M., Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, will auction Edouard Manet's ''Woman in a Garden,'' an 1882 oil on canvas (up to $125,000); an 1882 Renoir ''Landscape,'' an oil on canvas with stamped signature (up to $100,000); Eugene Boudin's ''The Port at St.-Vaast-La-Hougue'' of 1892 (up to $65,000), and Georges Rouault's ''The Fisherman,'' an oil on paper laid down on canvas, of unknown date (up to $60,000).

docs.snippet: Many of the fans at Fort Lauderdale Stadium watching the free daily workouts and collecting autographs do not recognize the Yankee running down grounders at third base.   He is Joe Lefebvre, who had a fling in the Yankee outfield last summer when ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Many of the fans at Fort Lauderdale Stadium watching the free daily workouts and collecting autographs do not recognize the Yankee running down grounders at third base. He is Joe Lefebvre, who had a fling in the Yankee outfield last summer when Oscar Gamble was injured, and then returned to New York's Triple A team in Columbus, Ohio. This year, Lefebvre, a strong-armed 24-year-old, is trying to learn a new position and improve his chances of making a team overstocked with outfielders. ''I'd love to play there,'' Lefebvre said. ''I'd love to play anywhere. If third base is an in for me to make the big leagues, great.''

headline.main: Yanks Give Lefebvre a Shot at Third Base

byline.original: By JANE GROSS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: In something of a surprise, two movies about different sorts of grotesque human beings tied with the most nominations for the 53d Academy Awards.   ''The Elephant Man,'' the grim true story of a deformed man with a gentle soul, won eight nominatio...
docs.lead_paragraph: In something of a surprise, two movies about different sorts of grotesque human beings tied with the most nominations for the 53d Academy Awards. ''The Elephant Man,'' the grim true story of a deformed man with a gentle soul, won eight nominations, including best picture; John Hurt as actor; David Lynch as director; art direction, costume design, film editing, original score and screenplay. ''Raging Bull,'' an unblinking look at the spiritual monstrosity of the boxer Jake LaMotta, won its nominations for best picture; Robert De Niro as actor; Martin Scorsese, director; Joe Pesci, supporting actor; Cathy Moriarty, supporting actress; cinematography, and sound. The other nominees for best picture were ''Coal Miner's Daughter,'' a look without rose-colored glasses at the life of Loretta Lynn, the country-and-western singer, and the third of the five nominated movies to be based on a real person; ''Ordinary People,'' the story of a family shattered by a catastrophe, and ''Tess,'' Roman Polanski's richly Romantic re-creation of Thomas Hardy's ''Tess of the D'Urbervilles.'' 8 for Mel Brooks Production ''Ordinary People,'' which was expected to sweep the nominations, ended up with six, tied with ''Tess,'' which had not been expected to do nearly so well. ''Coal Miner's Daughter'' received seven nominations. The big surprise was the eight nominations garnered by ''The Elephant Man,'' a Mel Brooks production not based on the Broadway play of the same name.

headline.main: 'ELEPHANT MAN' AND 'BULL' UP FOR 8 OSCARS EACH

byline.original: By ALJEAN HARMETZ, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Hemlines that shinny up and down the leg from season to season are not much use to anyone. Designers have found that they instill such feelings of apprehension and insecurity that they do not induce women to buy clothes of any kind, especially in ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Hemlines that shinny up and down the leg from season to season are not much use to anyone. Designers have found that they instill such feelings of apprehension and insecurity that they do not induce women to buy clothes of any kind, especially in a time of rising prices. A little more than a decade ago, women went through paroxysms as they shortened their dresses, as much as an inch or two a month, thinking each time they did so they looked a little younger. But the search proved as futile as Ponce de Leon's, and hemlines soon came tumbling down - first to the knees, then the calf, then even lower.

headline.main: HEMLINES: TREND IS DOWN, BUT ANYTHING IS ACCEPTABLE

docs.snippet: After a winter of hard work, Jim Spencer reported to the Yankees' early camp here 12 pounds lighter than last season and determined to avoid the slumps and sufferings of 1980.   ''It was partly my fault and partly the way I was handled,'' the firs...
docs.lead_paragraph: After a winter of hard work, Jim Spencer reported to the Yankees' early camp here 12 pounds lighter than last season and determined to avoid the slumps and sufferings of 1980. ''It was partly my fault and partly the way I was handled,'' the first baseman said of the drop in his batting average from .288 to .236 and his having been benched several times for weeks. ''If I thought it was all my fault, I'd say so, but there's no way I'll take all the blame.'' Spencer, who shares first-base duties with Bob Watson, admits that he reported to spring training last year out of shape. He believes, however, that under Dick Howser, then the manager, it was difficult, if not impossible, to work his way out of a slump because of the system of platooning players.

byline.original: By JANE GROSS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: As to the extent of the Irish contribution to world literature, everyone is more or less of the same mind. The history of poetry in the 20th century would have a big hole in it if W.B. Yeats were to be taken away. The history of the novel would la...
docs.lead_paragraph: As to the extent of the Irish contribution to world literature, everyone is more or less of the same mind. The history of poetry in the 20th century would have a big hole in it if W.B. Yeats were to be taken away. The history of the novel would lack central energy if no one mentioned James Joyce. It looks as if the plays of Oscar Wilde, J.M. Synge, Sean O'Casey and Samuel Beckett will be performed as long as people want to see live actors on a stage. Among storytellers, the Irish - from Somerville and Ross in the 1880's through Elizabeth Bowen and Sean O'Faolain and onward - have had the gift of making us sit up and say, ''What happened next?''

headline.main: Gallery View; THE WEALTH OF IRISH CONTRIBUTIONS
